awd_titl_txt: Using Muons and Protons to Probe the Structure of the Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary physics program supported by this award is the precise measurement of the muon magnetic moment. The muon is a fundamental particle with characteristics very similar to the electron, but with 200 times the mass. The ultimate goal is to compare the experimental measurement with theoretical predictions from the so-called Standard Model of Particle Physics. The current Standard Model cannot explain many observed phenomena, such as the nature of dark matter or the origins of the matter-antimatter asymmetry in our universe. If discovered, a significant discrepancy between the experimental measurement and Standard Model predictions could provide long awaited insights into the nature of Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) physics. In addition, this award will support investigations into how quarks and gluons fragment into the matter that makes up our universe. It is now a well-established fact that protons are made up of more elementary particles, called quarks and gluons, that are bound tightly inside the proton. When liberated, the quarks and gluons break up and produce a shower of matter and antimatter particles. Measurements supported by this award will shed light on the number and characteristics of the particles produced in these showers. The studies described here will provide graduate students with the necessary tools and knowledge to obtain post-doctoral work at other large colliders or smaller non-accelerator based collaborations. Undergraduate students funded by this award will continue to have the rare opportunity to experience the scientific culture and participate in experiments at National Laboratories.

The muon measurements will be performed by the new g-2 collaboration at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, which proposes to measure the muon anomalous magnetic moment to 140 parts per billion.  A deviation from the Standard Model prediction at the observed level could be explained by several BSM scenarios and the improved precision will significantly constrain key parameters in supersymmetry, one of the most widely discussed BSM models. The studies of proton structure measurements will be carried out at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory. The root(s) = 200GeV proton collisions necessary for these experiments are only available at RHIC. Jet reconstruction techniques will be used to measure yields of identified pions, kaons and protons inside of fully reconstructed jets. These yields will provide critical input on gluon and quark transverse momentum dependent fragmentation functions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Decades of experiments have given us a fascinating and intriguing picture of the universe. Nearly everything we see is made of electrons, photons, protons and neutrons. Electrons and photons are fundamental particles, but protons and neutrons are composed of smaller fundamental particles called quarks and gluons (partons). These partons are held inside of the proton and neutron by the strong force, a force so powerful that it produces an energetic shower of particles and antiparticles when we try to knock a single parton out of the parent proton or neutron. Physicists do not understand this process and how it depend on things like the type of parton or the spin of the parent proton, Furthermore, we know that these quarks, gluons, electrons and photons comprise less than 5% of the total universe! The rest is dark matter (27%) that we cannot see directly and dark energy (68%) that is causing the universe to rapidly expand. Physicists around the world are searching for new particles and forces that could explain the origin of dark matter and dark energy. This award provided support for the principle investigator and her group of three graduate students and one undergraduate student to pursue two experimental programs, each aimed at exploring the structure of our universe at the most fundamental levels.

The first experimental program is called g-2 and is sited at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory (Fermilab). This experiment aims to measure the deviation of the muon's magnetic moment from 2 (hence the name g-2!) to the extraordinarily precision of 140 parts-per-billion. All fundamental particles have a characteristic property called spin, which manifests as intrinsic angular momentum. If the particle is electrically charged this spin will induce a magnetic moment which results in the particle acting like a tiny magnet. In this case the fundamental particle is the muon which is essentially a heavy electron. The reason to focus on this particular property of the muon is that it is also possible for theorists to calculate the anomalous magnetic moment to the same precision measured in the g-2 experiment. This is important because a significant discrepancy between the theoretical prediction and the measurement would imply the existence of new particles and/or forces of nature. In the spring of 2021, the g-2 collaboration announced their first result from just a small subset of the total amount of data taken to date. The result is in excellent agreement with previous experiments and when combined with world data, demonstrated a tantalizing 4.2s deviation from the theoretical predictions published the previous year!  The experiment continues to take data and analyze new datasets with an updated result expected in 2023.

The second experimental program uses the STAR detector at the Brookhaven National Laboratory to map out how quarks and gluons hadronize, that is how they fragment and coalesce back into the particles that make up our visible universe. Due to the nature of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the formal theory of strong interactions, it is not possible to theoretically calculate the probability that a parton will hadronize into another particle, or perhaps even more interestingly, the spatial and momentum distributions of these final state particles with respect to the parent parton. These functions must be extracted from particle correlations in the debris created from collisions of high energy particles.The PI and her group is in the process of analyzing data from proton-proton and proton-Gold collisions collected by the STAR collaboration. This data will shed light on these hadronization effects and how they change in nuclear matter.   This award was also used to support the construction and installation of a new detector in the forward region of the existing STAR detector.  This forward detector will push the ongoing studies of quarks and gluons and the nature of QCD into a new kinematic regime, previously inaccessible to the STAR detector. 

The broader impacts resulting from this funding are the exposure and education of students to fundamental nuclear physics. The studies described here provide graduate students with the necessary tools and knowledge to obtain post-doctoral work on a wide variety of nuclear physics experiments, thereby supporting the future of our discipline and the operation of our national laboratories. The impact is not limited to the field of nuclear physics. Because the training in computing, machine learning algorithms, detector technologies and problem solving is very broad, it allows students to pursue careers in the private sector where they can make significant contributions at technology start-ups, at financial institutions and science policy agencies. For example, students doing research in this group have gone on to work at Google and Spotify, while others become physics professors at universities located in eastern Kentucky and India. All these students were exposed to similar research experiences and use them to serve different scientific goals and populations.
